article.title: Primordial gravitational waves amplification from causal fluids

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the black solid line in Figure 1 represent?
choices: The scale factor of the Universe
The physical wavelength of the perturbations
The Hubble radius
The temperature of the Universe

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the shaded zone in Figure 1?
choices: It represents modes that re-enter the horizon before the electroweak transition.
It represents modes that are amplified due to fluid-graviton interaction.
It represents modes that are suppressed due to fluid-graviton interaction.
It represents modes that remain outside the horizon until today.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the horizontal line labeled "λτ" represent?
choices: The physical wavelength corresponding to the Hubble radius at the end of inflation.
The physical wavelength corresponding to the relaxation time of the fluid.
The physical wavelength corresponding to the electroweak transition.
The physical wavelength corresponding to the present time.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true based on Figure 1?
choices: The physical wavelengths of perturbations grow proportionally to the scale factor.
Modes with smaller wavenumbers re-enter the horizon later.
The Hubble radius always increases with time.
The electroweak transition occurs before matter-radiation equality.
The evolution of the Hubble parameter.
The temperature anisotropy of the Cosmic Microwave Background.
The primordial gravitational wave spectrum for a certain range of modes.
The relaxation time of a scalar field.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the factor 1.35 in formula (61)?
choices: It represents the tensor-to-scalar ratio.
It represents the amplification of the gravitational wave spectrum due to fluid-graviton interaction.
It represents the redshift at the electroweak transition.
It represents the number of relativistic degrees of freedom.

multiple_choice_question.text: What range of wavenumbers does formula (61) apply to?
choices: All super-Hubble modes.
All sub-Hubble modes.
Modes with wavenumbers smaller than the inverse relaxation time.
Modes with wavenumbers between the inverse relaxation time and the wavenumber corresponding to the electroweak transition.

multiple_choice_question.text: What would happen to the amplification factor if the interaction between gravitons and the fluid were stronger?
choices: It would stay the same.
It would increase.
It would decrease.
It would oscillate.
